reviewText: Robert Donat plays a threadbare young Scot forced to sell the family castle and also plays his two-hundred-year-old ghostly ancestor, uprooted when the castle is sold and moved, "stone by stone and panel by panel," to Florida. Eugene Pallette, best known as the long-suffering father in "My Man Godfrey," is a much more buoyant personality in this film, but Jean Parker, a sort of low-rent Jean Arthur, is sweet but a bit washed-out as the love interest. Elsa Lanchester makes maximum impact in the bit part of a richly contemptuous psychic investigator, a role apparently trimmed. (Listen closely, and you'll notice her character's name is mentioned in the ship sequence.) The music is a bit sparse, but well used when it IS used. Most of the comedy is provided by amusing but predictable satire of Scottish and American national character, and there are some moments of sublime silliness. Donat provides the rest of the sublimity. His modern self is a rather dull fellow, but the ghost is a keeper, in full Highland dress, and with both a spectral gravity and an impish charm left over from his pre-limbo womanizing. Over the years I think I've even finally answered the riddle: "What is the difference between a thistle in the heather and a kiss in the dark?" K-I-L-L-I-E-C-R-A---
Love this movie. It has it's "flaws, but it's old. I love these old movies so I'm very forgiving. Family fun.
Great quality for a very old movie! I'd buy movies from "Amazon" any day.
Cute silly story. If you like old black and white movies, this is a great one at Halloween time.
Excellent fantasy - comedy.  I enjoyed the Scottish kilts, and Robert Donat.
A really good story line with a good sense of humor such as the Canterville Ghost.  A ghost go west, his castle also, and finds peace in America.
great price
The DVD arrived on time. It's a favorite movie of mine and I was extremely pleased to have it again.
Loved it, great fun with lots of "warm" moments. Recommended for those that like movies from this era.
Fun flick from the past. The next step is blu-ray. Good that some of the classic actors of the past get a new-go-around.

The story  was great. i wanted to see this movie for a long time.
I was not disappointed in the story and I will watch this again.
Imaginative; clever; light-hearted approach to the supernatural.  Good storytelling.  Well-cast with Robert Donat playing a double roll.  Eugene Pallette was good, too.

"The Ghost Goes West" is another comedy by Rene Clair, one of the well-known directors of the cinema.  It satirizes misconceptions about Scotland and ends in a finale which is almost slapstick.  A most amusing performance.
I love old movies and this was an interesting subject matter that I had read about in a movie database.
I love Robort Donat.  I try and see everything he has done.  The Ghost Goes West was classic Donat and his charm shined through as always.

Having suffered through some "pretend" picture quality on this title, I was hoping for the best but ready for more of the same. I'm pleased that material this good still survives. You will be happy to introduce this charming film to friends starring an actor who left us way too soon. One of the seminal ghost comedies and a joy to behold.

I ordered this movie on a whim.  I was ordering the old Canterbury Ghost and I remembered this one from my old movie watching days.  It is similar in nature to the Canterville Ghost, except there is no kid .... more of a romantic comedy with a ghost.  Perfect for a lazy winter day.... Very funny.  Dated material and black and white is probably a turn-off to today's kids.

The print, apparently made when ordered, is in excellent condition.

The Ghost Goes West is one of those gems that nobody knows about.  It is funny, charming, and surprisingly romantic.  Not for the Bruce Willis crowd.  But if you want a funny, witty hour-plus of entertainment this film will not disappoint you.  The sound is typical of early British cinema- kind of poor- but turn it up a bit higher and it's just fine.  Under this label it's a GREAT print too.

I should mention that we recorded it on Beta about 20 years ago off TV when AMC found and broadcast it, and we've been living with that since then and I am so happy that it's available commercially.

Of all the great European directors who came to Hollywood in the thirties and forties, Ren Clair may have enjoyed the most successful exile, directing the classics I MARRIED A WITCH and AND THEN THERE WERE NONE. But, before traveling from Paris over the Atlantic to the New World, Clair enjoyed a brief sojourn in Great Britain, where he made this marvelous and unjustly neglected comedy.
The plot is simple: a land rich/cash poor Scotsman sells the family castle to a rich American millionaire, who has the castle moved to the US stone by stone. The difficulty is that the castle is haunted, and the ghost moves with the castle to its new locale. We therefore get a ghost fantasy with a different twist: a ghost has to deal with culture shock.

For me, three things make this film stand out. First, Robert Donat is marvelous as the ghost/impoverished seller. Had Donat lived later in the 20th century, he would have been far, far more successful as an actor, and infinitely more active. Donat suffered from nearly debilitating asthma condition that severely limited his screen appearances (as well as some serious stage fright, or, in this case, screen fright). This performance is one of his finest. Second, Eugene Pallette enjoys one of his greatest roles. Pallette is perhaps best known as Friar Tuck in the Errol Flynn THE ADVENTURES OF ROBIN HOOD, and almost as well known in THE LADY EVE and MY MAN GODFREY. He actually appeared in a vast number of films from the beginning of the silent era all the way to his death in 1946. Yet, his major roles were relatively few. I find his stern scowl, rotund physique, and softhearted core to be enchanting. The third reason the film succeeds is the deft and light-hearted direction of Ren Clair. Partly because he suffered a sharp post-WW II decline, Clair is not as fondly remembered as he ought to be. He directed the two Hollywood classic I mentioned above, but was even better in the early 1930s, directing in France such masterpieces as SOUS LES TOITS DE PARIS and  NOUS LA LIBERTE, as well as one of my all time favorite films, the utterly delightful musical LE MILLION.

I first saw thi movie on TV 50 years ago.and have loved it ever since. As I understand it , the reason why it has poor sound and picture quality is it was poorly preserved over the years and as a result it deteriated ,but I still love it. It may never be available again, sad to say. WM

I saw this movie in the theater when I was about 12 and remembered it fondly. Recently, I found this DVD version and it is still enjoyable although the print is poor and sound pretty mushy. It was made about 1934 and sound was problematic in those days anyway. The story is of a Scottish laird who is more interested in romancing girls than fighting in the war and, as a result, gets blown up. The accidental death is handled with a bit of heavy handed humor and a rival clan is implicated in the event. The ghost of the laird is ordered by his departed father to remain haunting the castle until he revenges the family honor on a descendent of the offending rival clan. This is greatly complicated by the sale of the castle by the last of the family who is broke and glad to be rid of it. The castle is dismantled and shipped to Florida accompanied by the ghost. Robert Donat plays both parts and the romantic interest, the daughter of the rich businessman who buys the castle, is played by a pretty actress I have not seen in anything else. One novelty is a thin and pretty Elsa Lancaster, playing a small part. It is still not bad but the quality of reproduction is pretty poor.
Excellent movie
A Scottish Ghost is taken to Florida, USA, to find the last survivor of his rival clan and redeem himself from his father's curse. Good tale, well played.
Very enjoyable Hollywood fantasy film.

This is a charming movie from the mid thirties.  No sex, no violence (well, the ghost is the result of an unfortunate encounter with a stray cannon ball, but there is no blood and gore) just a light comedy that still can be appreciated by modern audiences.

Robert Donat of "Goodbye Mr. Chip's" fame is the star of this fantasy tale.  All about a castle bought by american millionaire Eugene Pallette, who brings the castle home to America, Lock, Stock and resident Ghost (Donat).  It is a charming ghost story with even a ghostly romance.  Fun for the whole family.  Sit down with some popcorn and soda's and enjoy!
My mom introduced me to the whimsical romantic story when I was a kid.  Robert Donat is absolutely charming.  If you like him, I think you'll love this movie.
Another Donat exceptional movie with a good video quality. It arrived within time guidelines.

The special effects are quite good for a movie of its era. The story
MIGHT seem familiar if you're a "Twilight Zone" fan. Rod Serling re-
worked it for one my favorite episodes with Burgess Meredith, and,
Don Rickles. It was aired on 3/3/'61, "MR DINGLE, THE STRONG".
The plot----there----is changed a bit to being galactic-aliens giving
Mister Dingle the strength of 300 men... and the intelligence of the
300 brightest minds.... no, wait... that was THE MAN THAT COULD
WORK MIRACLES... this is sorta like THE CANTERVILLE GHOST
(1944)... just older. Get all three... AND The Twilight Zone, too!
Fascinating old movie.  Shipped quickly, thank you!
A little silly, but good fun
